thread.title: Dolphins: Dan Campbell knocked the dull out of Dolphins
thread.title_full: Miami Dolphins: Dan Campbell knocked the dull out of Dolphins | www.palmbeachpost.com

author: Dave George
title: Dolphins: Dan Campbell knocked the dull out of Dolphins
text:
The ice bucket bath came for interim head coach Dan Campbell with 16 seconds remaining in his own personal Music City miracle.
For followers of the Dolphins, a similar shock of adrenalin and surprise came much sooner, maybe at halftime when people in living rooms and bars and parties across South Florida looked up and saw a 17-3 Miami lead and wondered hey, was there actually a real team buried under all that gunk?
 interim head coach Dan Campbell runs off the field after 38-10 win at Or maybe it was in the fourth quarter, when Ryan Tannehill came out throwing deep from his own goal line and in no time flat the Dolphins had driven 97 yards for a tack-on touchdown in a stunning 38-10 road win over the Tennessee Titans. Yeah, that had a lot of fans stuck between a high-five and a hallelujah, too, all the while asking themselves if it could really be true.
“That’s just one game and we’ve got Houston next week so I don’t want to go too far with it,” Campbell sternly informed reporters who were eager to multiply this dramatic victory into much more.
Sure, just one, like Everest is one mountain, like Godzilla was one lizard.
Miami Dolphins interim head coach Dan Campbell calls a timeout near the end of the first quarter with assistant head coach Darren Rizzi (left) at What we just witnessed, friends, was the largest margin of victory for a head coaching debut in Dolphins franchise history, and it was achieved by a former tight ends coach who took this job on as if he were jumping aboard a moving train. It takes a little boldness to do that. A little crazy, too.
Let’s not kid ourselves, though. The most valuable commodity that Campbell brought to Nissan Stadium Sunday was the simple fact that he is not Joe Philbin. The Dolphins tried that, the steady hand, the calming influence, the organized mind, and all it got them was three seasons of mediocrity and a bonus month of misery that owner Stephen Ross could have avoided by making a coaching change in December.
Campbell, 39, would have been a strange choice back then, never having head coached so much as a preseason game or an intrasquad scrimmage. At the moment, however, he is the perfect slap in the face, turning practice into a series of desperate one-on-one clashes, chipping layers of rust off stars who had forgotten how to shine.
 Ryan Tannehill is one of those. He completed 22-of-29 passes with two touchdowns, but talked more about the way Campbell “energized” the team the moment he took over and how the new boss wants to establish a mindset of “setting the tone up front.”
That refers to letting the offensive line lead rather than cowering in the confusion of who is playing what position, and the mystery of how a couple of long-time offensive line coaches, Tony Sparano and Philbin, could fail to build the unit into something dangerous.
Campbell and offensive coordinator Bill Lazor risked an entire game plan on getting more from the same pestered players, plus first-time starter Billy Turner at right guard, and the reward was a 113-yard rushing day by Lamar Miller and a subsequent refreshing of Tannehill’s play-action game.
“The first thing I thought of was college, running the ball and trying to be physical,” said Turner, who was a real steamroller at small-school power North Dakota State. “I talked to coach Campbell one day after practice and it wasn’t even about football. It was more of a man-to-man talk.”
“Are you ready to do something big?” Probably something like that, something more than are you comfortable in knowing your assignments, like Philbin might have asked Turner, providing he spent much personal time with the underused second-year player at all.
Hey, it’s not always going to be so stark a contrast. The Dolphins haven’t changed players. They haven’t devised new schemes like the funky Wildcat formation of 2008. More than anything, they just got honest with themselves, about how much more they can give, and it was Campbell, the guy so nervous he worried about throwing up on his shoes, who threw that figurative ice bucket on them.
“Our sideline was in it,” said Campbell, an NFL player himself just six years ago. “When the defense was out there, we’ve got offensive players yelling, and vice versa. We haven’t had that.”
The Dolphins haven’t had much of anything, to be honest, since that wobbly and somewhat unsettling win to open the season at Washington. Now they are 2-3. That, in combination with all this rah-rah talk, isn’t even enough to make Bill Belichick blink.
Miami may actually have a team worth watching again, though, and you can thank Campbell for that. He didn’t just push all the right buttons Sunday, including the tossing of his first red challenge flag, he pounded them.
And he had a blast doing it. Maybe Philbin did, too, back when he was the offensive coordinator of a Div. III national title team at Allegheny College, but let’s not talk about Joe anymore.
Let’s focus instead on what’s left of this Dolphins season, which probably still will fall short of the playoffs but no longer will be short on passion.
DOLPHIN HEAD COACHING DEBUTS
Coach 1st game Opponent Year
George Wilson Lost 23-14 Oakland 1966
Don Shula Lost 27-14 Boston 1970
Jimmy Johnson Won 24-10 New England 1996
Dave Wannstedt Won 23-0 Seattle 2000
Jim Bates Lost 24-17 Seattle 2004
Nick Saban Won 34-10 Denver 2005
Cam Cameron Lost 16-13 Washington 2007
Tony Sparano Lost 20-14 NY Jets 2008
Todd Bowles Won 30-23 Buffalo 2011
Joe Philbin Lost 30-10 Houston 2012
Dan Campbell Won 38-10 Tennessee 2015
</p
